12 Best Chess Openings That Every Beginner Should Know
Listen with Speechify
BY
JACK PURSEY
UPDATED MAR 16, 2023
Newcomers to chess should consider learning the following twelve openings to ensure they get off to a good start as both White and Black.

(Left) black and white chess pieces (Right) ruy lopez chess opening on 2d board
Chess has enjoyed a sharp rise in popularity over the last year. This began when Chess.com created their first PogChamps tournament on Twitch in 2020, which proved extremely popular thanks to thanks to streamers like Grandmaster Hikaru Nakamura, xQc, and Ludwig. The tournament has gone from strength to strength since, with celebrities outside of Twitch like Gregor Clegane and Rainn Wilson competing in the tournament since.

RELATED:
Common Mistakes New Players Need To Avoid

Furthermore, Netflix's hit series The Queen's Gambit spurred another wave of interest, which gave sites like Chess.com, Chess24, and Lichess huge increases in their player count. To help players who are new to the game, we've listed some of the best openings to get started with.

Notations showing how the pictured games were reached will be on the right-hand side of each picture. For those who are yet to learn chess notation, a handy guide can be found here.

Updated on March 16th, 2023, by Jack Pursey: Studying new openings can be a daunting task for newcomers to chess. Entire books have been written on chess openings, and many Grandmasters are still learning something new every day about opening patterns that have been around for centuries. However, learning new openings can also be great fun and is incredibly rewarding, as understanding even the basic principles of a handful of openings can significantly improve a beginner's game. To give newcomers to chess some more help, we've expanded this list of the best chess openings with some more useful information.



1
Scotch Game
Scotch Game on an online Chess board
The Scotch Game is an alternative to the popular Ruy Lopez system. The opening's main benefit is that it quickly gives White plenty of space, particularly for their two bishops, which are both given open diagonals.

The opening isn't without its issues, as it swiftly releases the tension and can make White's e4 pawn vulnerable later in the game. Still, it's a great opening to learn for those who want to gain early space and avoid all of the theory that comes with playing the Ruy Lopez.

Example Game To Study
Kasparov, Garry vs Karpov, Anatoly (1990)

1.e4 e5 2.Nf3 Nc6 3.d4 exd4 4.Nxd4 Nf6 5.Nxc6 bxc6 6.e5 Qe7 7.Qe2 Nd5 8.c4 Nb6 9.Nd2 Qe6 10.b3 a5 11.Bb2 Bb4 12.a3 Bxd2+ 13.Qxd2 d5 14.cxd5 cxd5 15.Rc1 O-O 16.Rxc7 Qg6 17.f3 Bf5 18.g4 Bb1 19.Bb5 Rac8 20.Rxc8 Rxc8 21.O-O h5 22.h3 hxg4 23.hxg4 Bc2 24.Qd4 Qe6 25.Rf2 Rc7 26.Rh2 Nd7 27.b4 axb4 28.axb4 Nf8 29.Bf1 Bb3 30.Bd3 Bc4 31.Bf5 Qe7 32.Qd2 Rc6 33.Bd4 Ra6 34.Bb1 Ra3 35.Rh3 Rb3 36.Bc2 Qxb4 37.Qf2 Ng6 38.e6 Rb1+ 39.Bxb1 Qxb1+ 40.Kh2 fxe6 41.Qb2 Qxb2+ 42.Bxb2 Nf4 43.Rh4 Nd3 44.Bc3 e5 45.Kg3 d4 46.Bd2 Bd5 47.Rh5 Kf7 48.Ba5 Ke6 49.Rh8 Nb2 50.Re8+ Kd6 51.Bb4+ Kc6 52.Rc8+ Kd7 53.Rc5 Ke6 54.Rc7 g6 55.Re7+ Kf6 56.Rd7 Ba2 57.Ra7 Bc4 58.Ba5 Bd3 59.f4 exf4+ 60.Kxf4 Bc2 61.Ra6+ Kf7 62.Ke5 Nd3+ 63.Kxd4 Nf2 64.g5 Bf5 65.Bd2 Ke7 66.Kd5 Ne4 67.Ra7+ Ke8 68.Be3 Nc3+ 69.Ke5 Kd8 70.Bb6+ Ke8 71.Rc7 Ne4 72.Be3 Ng3 73.Bf4 Nh5 74.Ra7 Kf8 75.Bh2 Ng7 76.Bg1 Nh5 77.Bc5+ Kg8 78.Kd6 Kf8 79.Bd4 Bg4 80.Be5 Bf5 81.Rh7 Kg8 82.Rc7 Kf8 83.Kc6 Kg8 84.Re7 Kf8 85.Bd6 Kg8 86.Re8+ Kf7 87.Re7+ Kg8 88.Be5 Kf8 89.Ra7 Bg4 90.Kd6 Bh3 91.Ra3 Bg4 92.Re3 Bf5 93.Kc7 Kf7 94.Kd8 Bg4 95.Bb2 Be6 96.Bc3 Bf5 97.Re7+ Kf8 98.Be5 Bd3 99.Ra7 Be4 100.Rc7 Bb1 101.Bd6+ Kg8 102.Ke7 1-0

2
Italian Game
italian game chess opening on 2d board
The Italian Game is believed to have originated in the 15th century, making it one of the oldest openings still commonly used today. White and Black both get some control of the center and open up space for their queen and bishop with the e pawn push. Both develop their knights as Black defends the e5 pawn that White is threatening.

RELATED:
Best Chess Video Games

The move Bc4 has multiple purposes. It puts pressure on Black's weak f7 square, develops a minor piece, helps control the center of the board, and allows White to castle on their next move. When playing as Black and in this position, be wary of the move Ng5, which sees White threaten to take the f7 pawn, forking the queen and rook. This is known as the Fried Liver Attack.

Example Game To Study
Loyd, Samuel vs Rosenthal, Samuel (1867)

1.e4 e5 2.Nf3 Nc6 3.Bc4 Bc5 4.d3 Nf6 5.Be3 Bb6 6.Nc3 d6 7.h3 Na5 8.Bb3 Nxb3 9.axb3 Be6 10.Nb5 Bxe3 11.fxe3 c6 12.Nc3 Qc7 13.g4 a6 14.d4 O-O-O 15.d5 Bd7 16.g5 Ne8 17.Nd2 c5 18.Nc4 h6 19.Qh5 Rf8 20.gxh6 Rh8 21.hxg7 Rxh5 22.g8=Q Rxh3 23.Rxh3 Bxh3 24.Nb5 Qe7 25.Qh7 Bg4 26.Na7+ Kb8 27.Rxa6 Nc7 28.Ra5 Qf6 29.Qh1 Rh8 30.Qf1 Bf3 31.Nb6 Qh4+ 32.Kd2 Qg4 33.Qxf3 Qxf3 34.Nd7+ Ka8 35.Nc6+ Na6 36.Nb6# 1-0


3
Ruy Lopez
ruy lopez chess opening on 2d board
The Ruy Lopez is similar to the Italian Game, but with the bishop on B5 instead of C5. Like the Italian Game, it's a solid opening as White has good control of the center with their pawn and knight and can castle with their next turn. The most common response for White in this position is a6, forcing White to decide what to do with their bishop. It may seem tempting to take the knight as it doubles Black's pawns. However, this is a dubious strategy as, generally speaking, bishops are slightly better than knights.

It may seem that if Black plays a6, White can take Black's knight, then capture the hanging pawn on e5 with their knight once it recaptures the bishop. However, this would allow Black to play either Qe7 or Qg5, causing problems for White.

Example Game To Study
Kasparov, Garry vs Smyslov, Vassily (1981)

1.e4 e5 2.Nf3 Nc6 3.Bb5 a6 4.Ba4 g6 5.d4 exd4 6.c3 Bg7 7.cxd4 b5 8.Bc2 d6 9.d5 Ne5 10.Nxe5 dxe5 11.a4 Bd7 12.Be3 Nf6 13.O-O O-O 14.Qd2 Ne8 15.Bc5 Nd6 16.axb5 Bxb5 17.Re1 Qd7 18.Nc3 Rfb8 19.b4 Bf8 20.Qg5 Qe7 21.Qe3 Qf6 22.Bd3 Bxd3 23.Qxd3 Nb5 24.Nxb5 axb5 25.Rxa8 Rxa8 26.Qxb5 Qa6 27.Qxa6 Rxa6 28.g4 Bd6 29.b5 Ra8 30.Bxd6 cxd6 31.b6 Rb8 32.Rb1 Kf8 33.Kf1 Ke7 34.Ke2 g5 35.Kd3 Kd7 36.Kc4 Rc8+ 37.Kb5 Rc2 38.Ra1 Rb2+ 39.Ka6 1-0


4
Nimzowitsch-Larsen Attack
Nimzowitsch Larsen Attack on an online chess board
The Nimzowitch-Larsen Attack is named after Aron Nimzowitsch and Bent Larsen, who both commonly played 1.b3 or 1. Nf3 2. b3. It's an uncommon opening, especially at the beginner level, which makes it a good opening for newcomers to learn, as their opponent will likely be unprepared for it.

The Nimzowitsch-Larsen Attack lets players put their dark-square bishop on b2 early in the game, which helps to control the center and also gives White a dangerous weapon against Black's kingside, especially if they castle on that side. A common tactic for Black is to try and block White's dark-squared bishop with their pawn structure and to attack White's kingside, which can be underdeveloped in the mid-game if White isn't careful.

The two most popular continuations from this position are 1. e5 2. Bb2 Nc6 3. e3 Nf6 4. Bb5 Bd6 and 1. e5 2. Bb2 Nc6 3. e3 d5 4. Bb5 Bd6. In both examples, White is trying to capture Black's knight and then take their pawn, which would be undefended.

Example Game To Study
Larsen, Bent vs Eley, Brian (1972)

1.b3 e5 2.Bb2 Nc6 3.e3 Nf6 4.Bb5 d6 5.Ne2 Bd7 6.0-0 Be7 7.f4 e4 8.Ng3 0-0 9.Bxc6 bxc6 10.c4 d5 11.Nc3 Re8 12.Rc1 Bg4 13.Nce2 Nd7 14.h3 Bxe2 15.Qxe2 Nc5 16.Qg4 g6 17.f5 Nd3 18.fxg6 hxg6 19.Rf7 Kf7 20.Rf1 Bf6 21.Bxf6 1-0

5
Sicilian Defense
sicilians defense chess opening on 2d board
The Sicilian Defense has become the most common response to e5, so it's certainly worth learning the move as both White and Black. However, the Sicilian Defense is a minefield when it comes to chess theory – entire books have been written about it. Therefore, the best strategy to adopt when encountering the opening as a beginner is to stick to basic opening principles -- control the center of the board, develop pieces, and castle early.

The idea behind c5 for Black is that it discourages White from playing d4, their ideal move. The most common move for White in this position is to play Nf3, with the idea of pushing d4 next move. If cxd4, White has the move Nxd4.

Example Game To Study
Fischer, Robert James vs Saidy, Anthony (1957)

1.e4 c5 2.Nf3 Nc6 3.d4 cxd4 4.Nxd4 Nf6 5.Nc3 d6 6.Bc4 Bd7 7.Bb3 e6 8.O-O Be7 9.Be3 O-O 10.f4 Nxd4 11.Bxd4 Bc6 12.Qe2 b5 13.Nxb5 Bxe4 14.Nxa7 e5 15.fxe5 dxe5 16.Be3 Qb8 17.Nb5 Bc6 18.Nc3 Qb4 19.Rad1 Ra5 20.Rd2 Qh4 21.Bb6 Rc5 22.Rd3 Rb8 23.Bxc5 Bxc5+ 24.Kh1 h5 25.Qxe5 Ba7 26.Qg3 1-0

6
French Defense
french defense chess opening on 2d board
The French Defense is the third most common response to e4, with e5 being the second. The idea is that Black wants to counter White by playing d5 next move, quickly challenging White for control of the center. It's a solid move for Black, as it usually leads to closed positions in the mid-game. This is handy when learning the game or playing against a higher-rated opponent.

However, the increase in defense creates an offensive issue. The main one is that Black will likely struggle to develop their light-squared bishop due to Black's pawn structure blocking it in. The most common continuation from this position is 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3, defending the e4 pawn with the knight.

Example Game To Study
Kosintseva, Tatiana vs Xu Yuhua (2006)

1.e4 e6 2.d4 d5 3.Nc3 Nf6 4.Bg5 dxe4 5.Nxe4 Be7 6.Bxf6 Bxf6 7.Nf3 O-O 8.Qd2 Nd7 9.O-O-O b6 10.Bd3 Bb7 11.h4 Be7 12.Neg5 Nf6 13.c3 Bxf3 14.gxf3 c5 15.Qc2 h6 16.Nh7 Re8 17.Nxf6+ Bxf6 18.dxc5 Qe7 19.c6 Bxh4 20.Ba6 Bg5+ 21.Kb1 Rad8 22.Qe4 Rxd1+ 23.Rxd1 Rd8 24.Bd3 Qc7 25.Rg1 Kf8 26.Qb4+ Be7 27.Qe4 Bf6 28.Qb4+ Kg8 29.Be4 Be5 30.Qc4 Rd2 31.a4 Kf8 32.Re1 h5 33.Bc2 Bf6 34.Qb4+ Be7 35.Qe4 Bf6 36.Qb4+ Kg8 37.Qe4 g6 38.Qe3 Rd8 39.Be4 Kg7 40.Rg1 h4 41.f4 Be7 42.f5 exf5 43.Bxf5 Bc5 44.Qf3 Rd2 45.Rg2 Qe5 46.Ka2 Bd6 47.Bd7 Qc5 48.Kb1 Qc4 49.Be8 Qb3 0-1

7
Caro Kann Defence
Caro Kann Defence on an online chess board
The Caro-Kann Defence is the fourth most popular response to 1. e4. The opening is similar to the French Defence (more on that later) in the sense that Black ideally wants to play 2. d5, quickly challenging White's e4 pawn for control of the center.

One of the main benefits of the Caro-Kann Defence in comparison to the French Defence is that Black's light-squared bishop doesn't tend to get blocked, though it does prevent Black from moving their knight to the c6 square.

Example Game To Study
Morozevich, Alexander vs Ivanchuk, Vassily (2004)

1.e4 c6 2.d4 d5 3.e5 Bf5 4.f4 e6 5.Nf3 c5 6.Be3 cxd4 7.Nxd4 Ne7 8.Bb5+ Nd7 9.O-O a6 10.Be2 g5 11.g4 gxf4 12.gxf5 Nxf5 13.Nxf5 fxe3 14.Nc3 Rg8+ 15.Kh1 Qg5 16.Bf3 Nxe5 17.Qe2 Qxf5 18.Bxd5 Qh3 19.Bxb7 Ra7 20.Bf3 Bh6 21.Ne4 Ke7 22.Qe1 f5 23.Qb4+ Kf7 24.Qd4 Nxf3 25.Qf6+ Ke8 26.Qxe6+ Kf8 27.Qf6+ Rf7 28.Qd6+ Kg7 29.Rg1+ Kh8 30.Nf6 0-1

8
Scholar's Mate
scholars mate chess opening on 2d board
The Scholar's Mate isn't a great opening to learn when aiming for chess improvement, but it's handy to know to avoid being beaten by it. White has checkmated Black in this position, as the king can't escape White's queen. Meanwhile, White's bishop prevents Black from capturing it.

RELATED:
Famous Chess Games Every Beginner Should Study

Thankfully, there are a few ways to combat this as Black. For starters, Black can play Nf6 on move 3, guarding the f7 square and simultaneously developing a minor piece. It also prevents White from moving their queen to h5, which is another way to deliver the early checkmate. Opening in this way isn't a good strategy for White, as it usually puts them in a poor position in the middle game due to their awkwardly placed queen.

Example Game To Study
Fontes, Carlos vs Pina, Vladimiro (2001)

1.e4 e5 2.Bc4 Nf6 3.Qf3 Bc5 4.a3 d6 5.b4 Bb6 6.Nc3 c6 7.Nge2 O-O 8.h3 Be6 9.d3 d5 10.Bb3 d4 11.Na4 Bc7 12.Nc5 Bxb3 13.Nxb3 Ne8 14.Ng3 g6 15.Bh6 Ng7 16.h4 a5 17.h5 axb4 18.Qg4 Qf6 19.Bg5 Qe6 20.Qh4 f6 21.hxg6 hxg6 22.Qh7+ Kf7 23.Nc5 Qe7 24.Rh6 Ke8 25.Qxg6+ Qf7 26.Qxf6 Rxa3 27.Rb1 Na6 28.Qxf7+ Kxf7 29.Nd7 Rg8 30.Nf6 Bd8 31.Nxg8 Bxg5 32.Rh8 Ra2 33.Nh6+ Kg6 34.Nhf5 Ne6 35.Nh4+ Kg7 36.Re8 Kf7 37.Rh8 Rxc2 38.Nf3 Bf6 39.Rh7+ Kg6 40.Rxb7 Nac5 41.R7xb4 Nxd3+ 42.Kd1 Nxb4 43.Rxb4 Rxf2 44.Rb6 Rxg2 45.Rxc6 Nd8 46.Nxe5+ Kg5 47.Nf3+ Kg4 48.Rxf6 Rxg3 49.Nxd4 Rd3+ 50.Ke2 Rxd4 51.Ke3 Ra4 52.Rf8 Ra3+ 53.Kf2 Ne6 54.Rf6 Nf4 55.e5 Ra5 56.e6 Re5 57.Kf1 Nxe6 58.Rf7 Nf4 59.Rf8 Kf3 0-1

9
Queen's Gambit
queens gambit chess opening on 2d board
The Queen's Gambit is an opening that new players may want to learn after watching the show of the same name. The move may seem odd to new players, as Black is free to take the unprotected c4 pawn. However, White is likely to win a pawn back. The most common way for White to win the pawn back is with the move e3, which opens up the bishop to capture Black's pawn. Black can continue trying to defend the pawn, though they will likely find themselves in an awkward position.

If Black doesn't take the pawn, then White enjoys decent control of the center and is free to start developing their pieces and get castled.

Example Game To Study
Kasparov, Garry vs Karpov, Anatoly (1986)

1.d4 d5 2.c4 e6 3.Nc3 Be7 4.cxd5 exd5 5.Bf4 Nf6 6.e3 O-O 7.Bd3 c5 8.Nf3 Nc6 9.O-O Bg4 10.dxc5 Bxc5 11.h3 Bxf3 12.Qxf3 d4 13.Ne4 Be7 14.Rad1 Qa5 15.Ng3 dxe3 16.fxe3 Qxa2 17.Nf5 Qe6 18.Bh6 Ne8 19.Qh5 g6 20.Qg4 Ne5 21.Qg3 Bf6 22.Bb5 Ng7 23.Bxg7 Bxg7 24.Rd6 Qb3 25.Nxg7 Qxb5 26.Nf5 Rad8 27.Rf6 Rd2 28.Qg5 Qxb2 29.Kh1 Kh8 30.Nd4 Rxd4 31.Qxe5 1-0

10
King's Indian Defense
kings indian defense chess opening on 2d board
The King's Indian Defense is a common response to White's d4 and c4 moves. Black intends to play g7 within their next few moves, allowing them to castle and develop some center control with their pieces rather than pawns. Generally speaking, this opening allows both players to comfortably start developing their minor pieces. It also allows them to castle within the first ten moves without any real trouble.

A common continuation from this position is 3. Nc3 Bg7 4. e4 d6 5. Nf3 O-O 6. Be2 e5. The move e5 challenges the center while White is ready to castle.

Example Game To Study
Robert Byrne vs Robert James Fischer (1963)

1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 g6 3.g3 c6 4.Bg2 d5 5.cxd5 cxd5 6.Nc3 Bg7 7.e3 O-O 8.Nge2 Nc6 9.O-O b6 10.b3 Ba6 11.Ba3 Re8 12.Qd2 e5 13.dxe5 Nxe5 14.Rfd1 Nd3 15.Qc2 Nxf2 16.Kxf2 Ng4+ 17.Kg1 Nxe3 18.Qd2 Nxg2 19.Kxg2 d4 20.Nxd4 Bb7+ 21.Kf1 Qd7 0-1

11
London System
london system chess opening on 2d board
The London System is very common for new players to learn as it usually allows White to safely develop their pieces and obtain a solid position moving into the mid-game. A common strategy for White in this position is to play e3 on their next turn; this defends White's dark-squared bishop while also allowing the light-squared to develop, letting White castle kingside.

A common continuation from here is 3. c5 4. e3 Nc6 5. c3 e6 6. Nbd2 Bd6, giving both players a solid position to begin the mid-game.

Example Game To Study
Carlsen, Magnus vs Caruana, Fabiano (2017)

1.d4 d5 2.Bf4 Nf6 3.e3 e6 4.Nf3 c5 5.c3 Nc6 6.Nbd2 Bd6 7.Bg3 O-O 8.Bb5 Bxg3 9.hxg3 Qb6 10.a4 h6 11.O-O Ne7 12.Qb3 Qc7 13.a5 Bd7 14.Be2 Ng6 15.Qa3 c4 16.b3 cxb3 17.Nxb3 Ne4 18.Rfc1 Bc6 19.c4 dxc4 20.Rxc4 Qd8 21.Nc5 Nd6 22.Rc2 Bd5 23.Bd3 b6 24.e4 bxc5 25.exd5 exd5 26.dxc5 Ne4 27.c6 Qc7 28.Qb3 Rfd8 29.Qb7 Rac8 30.Rb1 Qxa5 31.c7 Rf8 32.Qb5 Qa3 33.Qxd5 Nc3 34.Rxc3 Qxc3 35.Bxg6 Rxc7 36.Ne5 Qc5 37.Bxf7+ Rfxf7 38.Rb8+ 1-0

12
King's Indian Attack
kings indian attack chess opening on 2d board
The King's Indian Attack is a great opening for beginners as it's easy to learn, quickly gets White's king safe, and isn't a theoretical minefield like many of the e4 openings.

The King's Indian Attack is similar to the aforementioned King's Indian Defense, but with White having an extra tempo. The opening has similar benefits to the King's Indian Defense, as White aims to control the center while developing pieces and can castle within their first few moves after moving their light-squared bishop to g2.

After fianchettoing the bishop and casting, it's often a good idea to play d3. The purpose of d3 is that it stops Black from playing e4, opens a line for the dark-squared bishop, and also gives the b1 knight the option to go to the d2 square.

Example Game To Study
Vaganian, Rafael A vs Sveshnikov, Evgeny (1980)

1.Nf3 d5 2.g3 Nf6 3.Bg2 c6 4.O-O Bf5 5.d3 e6 6.Nbd2 Be7 7.Qe1 h6 8.e4 Bh7 9.Ne5 Nbd7 10.Nxd7 Nxd7 11.f4 O-O 12.Kh1 a5 13.g4 a4 14.f5 a3 15.b3 Re8 16.Rb1 exf5 17.gxf5 Qa5 18.exd5 cxd5 19.Qg3 Bb4 20.Nf3 Kh8 21.f6 Nxf6 22.Bxh6 Nh5 23.Qg4 Ra6 24.Ng5 Bg6 25.Nxf7+ Bxf7 26.Bxg7+ Nxg7 27.Rxf7 Bf8 28.Rbf1 Qc5 29.b4 Qd6 30.Rxg7 Bxg7 31.Qh5+ Qh6 32.Qxe8+ Kh7 33.Bxd5 Qh3 34.Be4+ Kh6 35.Rg1 1-0

conversation.content: As an AI language model, I am not physically able to go to school. However, I can provide information and assistance on various educational topics and support students in their learning journey.

Provide feedback on this draft: In growing up as humans, it is typical for us to take on the values and ethics of those around us. Even if these ethics are not applied consistently, we take them on without much question. One example of this is the relationship that humans have with non-human animals. Broadly speaking, humans tend to hold their lives with less regard and we don’t view taking anything from them (i.e. eggs, meat, etc.) as problematic. There are of course, multiple groups and philosophical positions that reject this. One example is veganism, which can defined as “a philosophy and way of living which seeks to exclude – as far as is possible and practicable – all forms of exploitation of, and cruelty to, animals for food, clothing or any other purpose” (The Vegan Society). Similar to other groups advocating for a cause, advertisements are a common way to attempt to spread the vegan message. One example of this is pictured above, created by the advocacy group “Go Vegan World.” As exemplified by this advertisement, dairy farming is a cruel and unnecessary industry that results in the needless suffering and death of countless animals; by significantly reducing our consumption of animal products or going vegan we can help to stop the suffering of not only dairy cows, but all animals subjugated by humans.
	The “Go Vegan World” advertisement offers a lot to examine, we see an image of a mother cow sharing an intimate moment with her calf. This is juxtaposed with text that explains standard practices of the dairy industry and the impact it has on the lives of the mother & child. The immediate surroundings of the mother and her child are not visible, but they appear to be in a field or pasture. The text next to the photo of the mother and her calf reads “Dairy Takes Babies” first and foremost, followed by “From Their Mothers.” The two lines are intentionally different colors, which seems to signal that both lines of text should be taken in individually, as well as together/as a whole. Below this is text explaining how dairy cows are treated, and how it results in premature death. The text also notes that this is as a direct result of the dairy industry taking all her children, so that her milk can be taken for human consumption. The implication being that once dairy cows are no longer able to produce milk, they are killed because they are considered to have no more use by the industry. It is clear by examining this advertisement that there are indeed ethical concerns with dairy products.
	A good advertisement delivers a clear message, and we can see that within this advertisement as well. Here an argument is being made that the consumption of dairy is unethical because of how dairy cows are treated. Specifically, because calves are separated from their mothers soon after birth. This is done so that the milk that was intended for their child can be taken for human consumption. Some have stated that “Modern dairy cows are not selected for their mothering abilities, so the instinct in them is not as strong as in beef cows” (Cherney). But regardless of this, the question becomes why do we look at the relationship as any less valuable than one between a human mother and child? Why do we view the dairy industry as anything other than exploitation? These are the questions that the advertisement wants viewers to ask themselves.
	We can further understand this advertisement using its rhetorical appeals. These include ethos, pathos, logos, kairos, and telos. Ethos, in this case, represents an attempt to appeal to the values and ethics of the audience. The argument being made with this is that the practices of the dairy industry as explained in the advertisement should not fall in line with what viewers consider to be ethical. Most individuals are ignorant to the realities of the dairy industry, but in viewing this advertisement they are given a glimpse. This gives viewers the opportunity to consider if these hard truths fall in line with their personal ethics or not. The advertisement also clearly wants to make viewers feel angry, upset, or concerned about the treatment of dairy cows and their children. This is the advertisement’s pathos, an appeal to the emotions of the audience. It is perhaps most exemplified in the statement “The dairy industry will take all her calves & all her milk. When she has nothing left to give, it will take her life at 6 years. Her natural lifespan is 25 years.”
	The advertisement also makes an appeal to the audience using logos, their sense of logic and reason. The rhetorical argument being made with logos in this advertisement is that the dairy industry is unnecessary. By encouraging the audience to go vegan, they are opened up to the idea that consuming dairy is not only unnecessary, but abstaining from it will result in reduced suffering of dairy cows. This works in conjunction with the advertisements use of kairos.

As an AI language model, I can provide feedback and suggestions on the draft provided. 

Overall, the draft provides a clear and concise analysis of the "Go Vegan World" advertisement and effectively highlights its rhetorical appeals, namely ethos, pathos, logos, kairos, and telos. The author presents a strong argument against the dairy industry and its treatment of dairy cows, and provides evidence and examples to support their claims. The language used in the draft is also clear and concise, making it easy for readers to understand and follow the author's points.

However, there are a few areas where the draft could be improved. Firstly, the introduction could benefit from a more engaging opening, as the first sentence feels somewhat generic and may not capture the reader's attention immediately. Additionally, while the analysis of the advertisement is well-written, the final paragraph feels somewhat rushed and could benefit from more detailed analysis or a stronger conclusion.

Furthermore, the draft would benefit from additional sources or evidence to support the claims made in the analysis. For example, when discussing how dairy cows are treated, providing statistics or additional information could strengthen the argument and make it more persuasive. Additionally, including counterarguments or conflicting viewpoints could provide a more balanced analysis of the issue and add depth to the discussion.

Overall, the draft shows promise and effectively presents a strong argument against the dairy industry's treatment of cows. With some additional revisions and improvements, the draft could become a compelling and insightful analysis of the "Go Vegan World" advertisement.

conversations.facetValue: write a proposal for a sales and marketing team to launch and advertise a new organic snack product, Salted Fish Skin, in Hong Kong.

allFacetValues.value: write a proposal for a sales and marketing team to launch and advertise a new organic snack product, Salted Fish Skin, in Hong Kong.
English
write a proposal for a sales and marketing team to launch and advertise a new organic snack product, Salted Fish Skin, in the Hong Kong market.

conversation.content:
Topic
You and your group mates are the sales and marketing team of a medium-sized manufacturer of organic snacks based in Hong Kong – All About Natural Limited. Mr Timothy Jones, the General Manager of the company asked you to write a proposal to launch and advertise the company’s new product, Salted Fish Skin. 

“Salted Fish Skin” is the first healthy and organic crisp product manufactured by your company. Unlike all other crisps sold in Hong Kong, our product has three flavours of sweet and sour, spicy and original but they are low sugar, low calories, and the source of the fish skin is from organic farms in Hong Kong. In addition, the snacks are added with vitamin C which is good for health.  A colleague from your team, Jen Lee, has conducted a market survey on the organic snacks in Hong Kong and has submitted a report.

Read the report and write up the whole proposal. Remember to make up any relevant and necessary information on your own and make your own recommendations based on the report and your personal knowledge and experience. 
 

All About Natural Limited
Memorandum
To: Sales and Marketing Team
From: Jen Lee, sales and marketing assistant
Date: 21 March 2022
Subject: Report of the market survey on organic snacks – fish skin crisps in Hong Kong

1. Terms of Reference
I refer to your memo instructing me to carry out a market survey on the major fish skin sold in Hong Kong and submit herewith a brief report. I am now giving you the details about the survey conducted during March this year.

2. Methods
a. Questionnaire
A questionnaire was designed to obtain information about the favourite fish skin crisps of the teenagers and working adults in Hong Kong. 
b. Subjects
2500 teenagers and working adults responded to our questionnaire. Both genders of them were randomly picked on the street and came from different age groups – the youngest being 15 and the oldest being 38. 
c. Procedure
Six of our colleagues spent two weeks interviewing the subjects on the street outside the entrance of three MTR stations – Causeway Bay, Tsim Sha Tsui, and Tsuen Wan.

3. Findings
-  28% of the respondents have never tried fish skin crisps (organic or inorganic).
-  72% indicated that they tried different kinds of fish skin crisps:
33 % (Original Salted Egg Fish Skin from Irvins)
23% (Salted Egg Fish Skin from Golden Duck)
21% (Crispy Fish Skin with Chilli Sauce from Max Oceans)
13% (Salted Egg Fish Skin with Seaweed from Golden Duck)
10% (Others) 
The remaining 10% did not have a specific preference and like trying new tastes.

4. Conclusion
Hong Kong has a large market for fish skin. At present, it seems that fish skin with salted egg yolk has dominated the local market. Plus the imported brands from Singapore and Malaysia have triggered fierce competition with us.  Having said that, our Salted Fish Skin have the following strengths: 
    - the product has three flavours of sweet and sour, spicy and original but not made with egg yolk, 
    - they are low sugar, low calories, 
    - the source of the fish skin is from organic farms in Hong Kong, and
    - the snacks are rich in vitamin C which is good for health. 
According to our questionnaires, quite a number of respondents like trying new tastes and this can be our “competitive edge”. 

Guidelines
1. Create a sales and marketing team (a group of 3-4 people).
2. Write ONE proposal together to launch and advertise the company’s new product, Salted Fish Skin.
3. Only hard copy (typed) is accepted.
4. Deadline: Week 15. 
5. Word limit: four pages (Times New Roman, 12 points, A4 size – double line spacing)
6. Please take reference of “Example 3 Memo Proposal – A Proposal of Advertising Campaign” in your lecture notes.

All About Natural Limited
Proposal to Launch and Advertise Salted Fish Skin

1. Introduction

All About Natural Limited is a medium-sized manufacturer of organic snacks based in Hong Kong. We are well-known for our high-quality, innovative, and organic products, which cater to the increasing demand for healthier food alternatives in the market. In line with our mission and objectives, we hereby present a proposal to launch and advertise our new product – Salted Fish Skin.

2. Background

Based on a market survey conducted by our colleague Jen Lee, it was found that Hong Kong has a large market for fish skin, with 72% of the research respondents having tried different types of fish skin crisps. Currently, imported brands dominate the local market, with fish skin with salted egg yolk being the most popular flavor. Our new product – Salted Fish Skin – is unique in its taste and health benefits. With three flavors – sweet and sour, spicy, and original – it is made from low sugar, low calories recipes, and locally sourced organic fish skin. Additionally, it is rich in Vitamin C, making it a healthier option compared to existing products.

3. Objectives

The primary objectives of this proposal are to:

  a. Launch our new product, Salted Fish Skin, in the Hong Kong market.
  b. Create a strong brand presence and generate market awareness for the product.
  c. Establish a significant market share in the organic snack industry.
  d. Drive sales and achieve revenue targets.
  
4. Strategy

To achieve the objectives mentioned above, we propose the following strategies:

  a. Product Launch: Organize a launch event that brings together influencers, media, and potential customers to introduce the product and create a buzz in the market.

  b. Advertising: Utilize various advertising channels such as print media, social media, and outdoor advertising to reach our target audience, which includes teenagers and working adults between 15 and 38 years old.

  c. Promotions and Offers: Offer limited-time promotions and discounts to incentivize customers to try the product, and collaborate with popular retail outlets to improve product visibility.

  d. Public Relations: Engage in public relations activities, including press releases, media interviews, and partnership announcements to generate positive coverage and create a strong brand image.

  e. Influencer Marketing: Partner with popular food bloggers and influencers to promote our product and generate organic reviews and recommendations.

5. Implementation

The sales and marketing team will collaborate closely to ensure a seamless execution of the proposed strategies. The timeline for the implementation is as follows:

  a. 1st Month – Finalize product packaging, promotional materials, and event planning for the launch event.
  
  b. 2nd Month – Launch event, initiate advertising and promotional campaigns, and begin influencer marketing activities.
  
  c. 3rd Month – Evaluate the success of the launch, optimize marketing activities, and explore partnerships with retail outlets to extend product visibility.
  
  d. 4th to 6th Month – Maintain marketing and public relations efforts, assess progress, and make necessary adjustments to achieve objectives.

6. Budget

The proposed budget for the product launch and marketing activities:

  a. Product Launch Event: HKD 100,000
  b. Advertising (print, social media, and outdoor): HKD 300,000
  c. Promotions and Offers: HKD 50,000
  d. Public Relations: HKD 50,000
  e. Influencer Marketing: HKD 100,000
  f. Contingency (10% of the total budget): HKD 60,000
  TOTAL BUDGET: HKD 660,000

7. Conclusion

Salted Fish Skin has the potential to capture a significant share of the organic snack industry in Hong Kong, given its unique flavors and health benefits. Combining an effective marketing campaign with a strong product offering can significantly boost the product's popularity and lead to long-term success in the market. Therefore, we seek your approval for this proposal, as it will enable us to take the necessary steps to launch and advertise our new product, Salted Fish Skin, effectively in the local market.

Submitted by the Sales and Marketing Team:

1. (Name), Sales and Marketing Manager
2. (Name), Sales and Marketing Executive
3. (Name), Sales and Marketing Assistant
4. Jen Lee, Sales and Marketing Assistant

conversations.facetValue: explain the concepts and principles of Lean management.

allFacetValues.value: explain the concepts and principles of Lean management.
English
explain the concepts and principles of Lean management.

conversation.content: Explain the concepts and principles of Lean management.

Lean management is a continuous improvement approach to business operations that focus on enhancing customer value by optimizing the efficiency of resources, eliminating waste, and empowering employees. It originated with the Toyota Production System (TPS) and has since been adapted across various industries worldwide. The main concepts and principles of Lean management include:

1. Customer Value: The primary goal of Lean management is to create value for customers, which means understanding their needs and requirements and delivering products or services that satisfy those needs efficiently. Lean organizations aim to deliver the highest value to their customers while consuming the least possible resources.

2. Waste Elimination: Lean management identifies waste as anything that does not contribute to customer value. There are seven main types of waste in Lean: overproduction, waiting, transportation, over-processing, inventory, motion, and defects. By identifying and eliminating waste, organizations can experience increased productivity, reduced costs, and improved quality.

3. Continuous Improvement (Kaizen): Lean encourages the ongoing optimization of processes and practices by identifying areas of improvement and making incremental changes consistently. The idea behind Kaizen is that small, continuous improvements will accumulate over time, resulting in significant improvements in overall performance.

4. Respect for People: Lean management emphasizes the importance of engaging and empowering employees in order to achieve continuous improvement. By involving employees in problem-solving and decision-making, organizations can create a culture of teamwork, learning, and innovation.

5. Standardized Work: Standardization is essential in Lean management, as it promotes consistency, reduces variability, and enables organizations to identify and correct problems more easily. Implementing standardized work processes enables employees to perform tasks efficiently, reduces errors, and enhances communication.

6. Visual Management: A key aspect of Lean management is the use of visual tools to display information and make it easily accessible to all employees. These tools can include control charts, performance boards, and kanban systems. Visual management helps identify potential issues, track progress, and ensure that everyone is aware of the organization's goals and objectives.

7. Pull Systems: Lean management promotes a demand-driven approach to production and inventory management, as opposed to a push system. The pull system is based on producing goods or services only when there is a customer demand, which helps reduce inventory waste, cuts lead times, and minimizes production costs.

8. Flow: The concept of flow in Lean management refers to the steady and uninterrupted movement of materials, information, and work within a process. Lean organizations aim to create seamless flow by removing unnecessary steps, reducing bottlenecks, and balancing workloads.

9. Jidoka (Autonomation): This principle focuses on incorporating automation with a human touch. Jidoka enables machines to detect defects or system abnormalities and stop production when problems occur. This helps prevent the production of defective products and allows operators to focus on more value-added tasks.

10. Genchi Genbutsu (Go and See): Lean management encourages leaders and employees to see the actual situation on the shop floor and gather real-time information through personal observation. By engaging in Genchi Genbutsu, decision-makers can gain a better understanding of the production process, identify problems, and find opportunities for improvement.

Lean management is based on these principles and concepts to deliver quality products and services to customers with minimal waste, maximum efficiency, and continuous improvement. By engaging employees and fostering a culture of learning and innovation, organizations can achieve greater levels of success in their operations.

conversations.facetValue: explain the concepts and principles of Lean management.

allFacetValues.value: explain the concepts and principles of Lean management.
English
provide an explanation of the concepts and principles of Lean management.

conversation.content: Explain the concepts and principles of Lean management

Lean management is a philosophy and approach to business that seeks to minimize waste, increase efficiency, and continuously improve processes to deliver maximum value to customers. Lean management principles were initially developed in the Japanese manufacturing industry, notably by Toyota, but have since been applied across various industries and sectors worldwide. The core concepts and principles of Lean management include:

1. Value: In the context of Lean management, value refers to anything that a customer is willing to pay for, i.e., products or services that meet their needs and preferences. The primary aim of Lean is to identify and deliver value to customers.

2. Value Stream Mapping: Value stream mapping is an essential tool used in Lean management to visualize the flow of materials and information through the entire production process. The purpose of value stream mapping is to identify steps that add value and those that are wasteful, enabling organizations to optimize their production processes.

3. Continuous Improvement: Lean management emphasizes constant refinement and improvement of processes and practices. This principle often known as kaizen, encourages individuals and teams to identify problems, propose solutions, and engage in ongoing experimentation to optimize workflows.

4. Elimination of Waste (Muda): Waste refers to any activity or resource that consumes time, effort, or money without contributing to value creation. Lean management seeks to eliminate all types of waste from the production process – including overproduction, waiting time, transportation, excess inventory, extra motion, defects, and unnecessary processing.

5. Just-in-Time (JIT) Production: The JIT principle advocates for the production of goods/services only when there is a demand for them. It aims to eliminate waste that stems from overproduction and excess inventory by synchronizing the supply of materials to match customer demand.

6. Standardization of Work: Lean management champions the standardization of work processes to ensure consistency, quality, and efficiency. Standard work procedures provide a baseline for continuous improvement, making it easier to identify deviations, eliminate waste, and optimize processes.

7. Respect for People: Lean management acknowledges that sustainable success comes from recognizing and respecting the contributions of employees at all levels of an organization. This principle underscores the importance of promoting open communication, collaboration, and personal development to foster a culture of continuous improvement.

8. Visual Management: Lean management uses visual cues, such as charts, labels, and color-coding, to make workplace processes and performance metrics easily accessible and understandable to everyone. Visual management tools help to create a transparent work environment, promote accountability, and enable rapid problem-solving.

9. Pull Systems: In a pull system, the production process is driven by customer demand, rather than forecasting. This principle ensures that resources are allocated more efficiently and waste from overproduction is minimized.

10. Total Quality Management (TQM): Lean management embraces TQM, which promotes the pursuit of quality through continuous improvement and employee involvement. This approach fosters a culture where everyone takes responsibility for maintaining high product/service quality levels and addressing quality issues when they arise.

By applying the lean management principles and concepts, organizations can optimize their workflows, minimize waste, improve quality, and increase customer satisfaction.

English
explain Lean management concepts and discuss its evolution and challenges.

conversation.content: Explain the concepts and principles of Lean management

Lean management is a business philosophy and approach that aims to create the most value for customers while minimizing waste and continuously improving processes. It originated from the Japanese manufacturing industry, particularly from the Toyota Production System, and has since been adopted across various industries worldwide. Lean management focuses on reducing waste, improving efficiency, and maximizing value to customers. Here are some of the core concepts and principles of Lean management:

1. Value: The primary goal of Lean management is to deliver value to the customers. Value is what the customer is willing to pay for a product or service. Businesses should aim to provide the highest quality products or services at the lowest possible cost to maximize value for their customers.

2. Waste elimination: Lean management seeks to identify and eliminate all forms of waste in an organization. Waste can be in the form of overproduction, waiting time, transportation, unnecessary inventory, over-processing, defects, and unused talent. By eliminating waste, companies can create more value with fewer resources and improve overall efficiency.

3. Continuous improvement: Lean management promotes a culture of continuous improvement, also known as kaizen. This means that businesses should always be looking for ways to improve their processes, products, and services to better meet customers' needs. Continuous improvement involves regularly evaluating processes, identifying areas for improvement, and implementing necessary changes.

4. Just-In-Time (JIT) production: Lean management emphasizes producing and delivering products or services only when they are needed, in the right quantity, and at the right time. JIT production aims to minimize inventory, reduce lead times, and increase efficiency by focusing on demand-driven production.

5. Standardization: Standardizing processes is key to improving efficiency and reducing waste in Lean management. By creating standard work procedures, businesses can establish best practices, improve consistency, and reduce variability in their operations.

6. Visual management: Lean management encourages the use of visual management tools, such as charts, graphs, and visual cues, to help employees better understand and follow processes, track performance indicators, and identify areas for improvement.

7. Empowerment of employees: Lean management recognizes the importance of having knowledgeable and skilled employees involved in decision-making and process improvements. By empowering employees to identify and solve problems, companies can enhance their problem-solving abilities and promote a sense of ownership and accountability among team members.

8. Pull System: Instead of pushing products or services through the system based on forecasts, the pull system focuses on producing and delivering products or services according to actual customer demand. This reduces inventory, decreases lead time, and boosts overall efficiency by avoiding overproduction.

9. Total Quality Management (TQM): Lean management stresses the need for a strong focus on quality at every level of the organization. TQM ensures that every employee is responsible for delivering high-quality products or services, and any errors or defects are identified and corrected as early as possible in the process.

10. Value stream mapping: A value stream map is a visual representation of the steps involved in creating and delivering a product or service to customers. It helps identify sources of waste and areas for improvement, enabling businesses to optimize their processes for maximum efficiency and value creation.

In summary, Lean management is a comprehensive approach that aims to maximize value for customers by reducing waste, improving processes, and empowering employees. By adopting these principles, companies can enhance their competitive advantage, increase customer satisfaction, and achieve long-term success.

Discuss how Lean has evolved over time 
and what are the key challenges faced by organisations to implement lean management.

Lean management has evolved over time from its origins in the Toyota Production System to a broader approach that can be applied across various industries and organizations. Here are some notable developments in the evolution of Lean management:

1. Origins in the Toyota Production System (TPS): Lean management originated in the Japanese automobile industry, specifically from the TPS, developed by Taiichi Ohno and his team in the early 20th century. TPS aimed to reduce wasteful practices and improve efficiency in manufacturing, giving rise to many of the Lean principles we know today, such as JIT production, waste elimination, and continuous improvement.

2. Adaptation to other industries: Lean started as a manufacturing-focused approach, but over time, its principles and concepts have been applied across different industries, including healthcare, construction, software development, and the service sector. This shift has led to the understanding that Lean management can be beneficial for any organization seeking to improve its processes and deliver value.

3. Integration with other management approaches: Lean management has been integrated with other popular management methodologies, such as Six Sigma, creating approaches like Lean Six Sigma that combine the best practices of both methodologies. These hybrid methodologies aim to achieve operational excellence through continuous improvement, waste reduction, and data-driven decision-making.

4. Focus on organizational culture: As Lean management has evolved, it has been recognized that its principles must be supported by a strong organizational culture that values learning, continuous improvement, and employee empowerment. This emphasis on culture has led to the development of the Lean leadership concept, focusing on how leaders can foster a Lean culture and facilitate change management.

Despite these advancements, organizations still face several key challenges when implementing Lean management:

1. Resistance to change: Change is often met with resistance from employees, who may be threatened by potential job losses or uncertainty. Overcoming resistance and fostering buy-in from employees is crucial for the successful adoption of Lean principles.

2. Lack of understanding: Many organizations struggle to comprehend the core concepts and principles of Lean fully. This lack of understanding can lead to partial or incorrect implementation, yielding limited results, and causing frustration among employees.

3. Inadequate training and support: Implementing Lean management requires training and support for employees to understand Lean principles, tools, and techniques. Insufficient training and resources can lead to misunderstandings and poor execution of Lean initiatives.

4. Short-term focus: Some organizations see Lean management as a quick fix for their problems and may fail to recognize that Lean is a long-term journey that requires continuous improvement and ongoing effort.

5. Inconsistent commitment from leadership: The success of Lean management relies on strong commitment and support from leadership. If leaders fail to demonstrate their commitment or provide the necessary support, employees may become disengaged, and Lean initiatives may falter.

Smoothly implementing Lean management principles requires overcoming these challenges through effective communication, ongoing training, strong leadership, and fostering a culture of continuous improvement. A clear vision and focusing on long-term success are essential for any organization seeking to adopt Lean management.

conversations.facetValue: discuss the evolution of Lean management and the challenges organizations face when implementing it.

English
discuss the evolution of Lean management and the challenges organizations face when implementing it.

conversation.content: Discuss how Lean has evolved over time and what are the key challenges faced by organizations to implement lean management.

Lean has evolved significantly over time, adapting to the ever-changing landscape of business management and economic environments. Originally developed as the Toyota Production System (TPS) in the late 1940s, Lean has grown to become a widely recognized methodology for achieving operational excellence and eliminating waste. Its journey can be broadly divided into four phases:

1. Birth and development in the automotive industry (1940s-1970s): The principles of Lean were first formulated within Toyota as a response to the challenges faced during post-WWII Japan's rebuilding efforts. The focus was on reducing waste, improving quality, and increasing efficiency to lower costs.

2. Spread and adoption outside automotive (1980s-1990s): Lean started making its way into other industries, including manufacturing, aerospace, and even healthcare. A significant milestone was the publication of the book, "The Machine That Changed the World" by James P. Womack, which introduced the concepts of Lean to a wider audience.

3. Emergence of Lean consulting and training (1990s-2000s): With increasing demand for Lean know-how, many consulting firms started incorporating Lean services, offering customized training and implementation programs to clients.

4. Integration of Lean into other management philosophies (2000s-present): Lean has become a cornerstone of other management philosophies like Six Sigma (as Lean Six Sigma) and Agile software development. Today, Lean is no longer confined to manufacturing but has been embraced as a universal methodology for continuous improvement across various industries.

Despite its widespread acceptance, organizations often face several challenges when implementing Lean management:

1. Resistance to change: Lean initiatives often require a significant shift in organizational culture and mindset. This may provoke resistance from employees who are accustomed to traditional ways of working.

2. Inadequate leadership commitment: The success of Lean initiatives is heavily dependent on strong commitment and support from top-level management. Without it, the workforce may not buy into the new processes and practices, leading to poor implementation.

3. Insufficient training: Lean management requires a solid understanding of its principles and tools. If employees aren't provided with adequate training, they may struggle to apply the concepts effectively and efficiently.

4. Poor communication: Lean initiatives need clear and consistent communication on goals, objectives, and expectations. When communication is lacking, employees may not understand what is expected of them, leading to confusion, frustration, and reduced effectiveness.

5. Short-term focus: Lean is a long-term, continuous improvement process that requires persistence and patience. However, many organizations instead focus on short-term gains, compromising the full benefits of Lean principles.

6. Overemphasis on tools and techniques: Organizations may become too focused on implementing Lean tools and techniques without fully embracing the cultural change needed for sustainable improvements.

To overcome these challenges, organizations should emphasize effective communication, provide adequate training, secure management support, and foster an organizational culture that embraces change and continuous improvement. By committing to the long-term and holistic principles of Lean, organizations can achieve lasting, sustainable outcomes.

a person could create a small solar panel at home with recyclable parts?

Yes, it is possible to create a small, homemade solar panel using recyclable materials, though its efficiency and power production may be significantly lower than that of a commercial solar panel. Here's a simplified guide to making a DIY solar panel with recyclable parts:

1. Obtain solar cells: Find salvageable solar cells from discarded solar panels, broken solar garden lights, or even buy some inexpensive solar cells online. Be cautious of the quality of used solar cells, as their efficiency may be compromised.

2. Arrange the solar cells: Plan the layout of the solar cells, typically in parallel or series, to achieve the desired voltage and current output. A series connection will increase voltage, while a parallel connection will increase current.

3. Create a frame: Use wood, plastic, or any other non-conductive frame material to hold the solar cells. Use a thin, transparent plastic sheet or tempered glass to create a protective cover for the front side of the solar panel.

4. Connect the solar cells: Solder the solar cells together according to the layout plan, using tabbing wire and a soldering iron. Be gentle, as solar cells are often fragile.

5. Mount the solar cells on the frame: Use a non-conductive adhesive, such as silicone caulk, to fix the solar cells onto the frame. Allow the adhesive to cure properly before proceeding.

6. Seal and protect the solar panel: Apply a layer of clear, outdoor-rated sealant, such as silicone, around the edges of the panel's cover to ensure it is weatherproof and protected from moisture.

7. Attach wires and a diode: Solder the wire connections to the positive and negative terminals of the solar panel. Attach a blocking diode to the positive terminal, which prevents current from flowing back into the solar panel during the night.

8. Test and use the panel: Use a multimeter to measure the voltage and current output before connecting it to a charge controller, battery, or other devices.

Keep in mind that creating a DIY solar panel may not result in the same efficiency or durability as a commercially manufactured solar panel. If you're considering powering your home or large appliances, consider investing in high-quality, commercial solar panels instead.

What can I use as a homemade deodorant?

Homemade deodorants can be made using natural ingredients that help absorb moisture, fight bacteria, and provide a pleasant scent. Here's a simple recipe for making your own natural deodorant:

Ingredients:
- 3 tablespoons of coconut oil
- 2 tablespoons of baking soda
- 2 tablespoons of cornstarch or arrowroot powder
- Optional: 5-10 drops of your favorite essential oil (such as lavender, tea tree, or eucalyptus) for fragrance

Instructions:

1. Mix the baking soda and cornstarch (or arrowroot powder) in a bowl.

2. Add the coconut oil to the mixture, and stir until well combined. The coconut oil helps moisturize and provides a smooth consistency to the deodorant.

3. If desired, add a few drops of your chosen essential oil to add fragrance and additional properties (for example, tea tree oil has antibacterial properties).

4. Transfer your homemade deodorant to a small, clean container with a lid. An old, cleaned-out deodorant stick container can also be used for easier application.

5. Apply a small amount of the deodorant to clean, dry underarms as needed. Be aware that homemade deodorants have a different texture that may take some getting used to.

Note: Some people might be sensitive to baking soda, which can cause irritation or redness. In such cases, reduce the amount of baking soda and increase the amount of cornstarch or arrowroot powder in the recipe. Patch test any homemade deodorant on a small area of your skin to ensure you do not have a reaction before applying to your underarms.
Can you show me other recipe with other ingredients?

Certainly! Here's another homemade deodorant recipe that uses different ingredients:

Ingredients:
- 3 tablespoons shea butter
- 3 tablespoons beeswax pellets
- 2 tablespoons diatomaceous earth (food-grade)
- 2 tablespoons bentonite clay
- 1 tablespoon virgin olive oil or sweet almond oil
- Optional: 5-10 drops of your favorite essential oil (such as lavender, bergamot, or rosemary)

Instructions:

1. In a double boiler, heat the shea butter and beeswax pellets until fully melted. If you don't have a double boiler, you can use a heat-safe glass bowl over a pot of simmering water.

2. Remove the melted shea butter and beeswax mixture from heat and allow it to cool for a couple of minutes.

3. Stir in the diatomaceous earth and bentonite clay. Mix well to combine. These ingredients help to absorb moisture and neutralize odor.

4. Add the olive oil or sweet almond oil to the mixture, stirring until fully incorporated. These oils provide a smoother consistency and moisturize your skin.

5. If desired, add your chosen essential oils to the mixture for fragrance and additional properties.

6. Pour the liquid homemade deodorant into a clean container, such as a small jar or an empty deodorant stick container, and let it cool and solidify.

7. Apply a small amount of the deodorant to clean, dry underarms as needed.

Always perform a patch test on a small area of your skin to ensure you do not have a reaction to the ingredients before applying the homemade deodorant to your underarms. Remember that individual results may vary, as body chemistry and sensitivities are different for everyone.
What is the most natural and effective way to treat vitiligo?

Vitiligo is a complex skin disorder, and there is no one-size-fits-all treatment. It's crucial to consult with a dermatologist or medical professional to determine the best course of action for your specific case. While the following natural approaches may offer some benefits, their effectiveness varies from person to person.

1. Ginkgo biloba: Some studies suggest that Ginkgo biloba, a herbal supplement, may slow down the progression of vitiligo and slightly improve repigmentation. However, more research is needed to establish its efficacy.

2. Vitamin D and B12: A deficiency in vitamin D and B12 has been linked to vitiligo. Consuming foods rich in these vitamins or taking supplements might help improve general skin health, but their impact on vitiligo is not yet fully established.

3. Sun protection: Excessive sun exposure may worsen vitiligo. Limit your sun exposure, wear protective clothing, and use a broad-spectrum sunscreen with an SPF 30 or higher. This will also help protect your affected areas from sunburn and skin cancer.

4. Topical treatments: While not entirely "natural," some over-the-counter creams and ointments, such as tacrolimus and pimecrolimus, may help with repigmentation by suppressing the immune system in the affected area. These options have fewer side effects compared to corticosteroid creams.

5. Self-tanners: Although not a treatment for vitiligo, using self-tanning products can help even out your skin tone and make vitiligo patches less noticeable.

6. Lifestyle: Maintaining a healthy lifestyle, reducing stress, and avoiding exposure to environmental irritants or allergens that can worsen your symptoms may help manage your vitiligo better.

7. Camouflage makeup and cosmetics: While not a treatment, using specialized makeup or cosmetics can help temporarily hide the appearance of vitiligo, improving your confidence and self-esteem.

It's important to remember that the effectiveness of these approaches can vary widely, and it's essential to consult with a dermatologist before starting any natural or alternative therapies for vitiligo.
What is the most effective cream recommended by the best dermatologists?

It's difficult to pinpoint a single "most effective" cream recommended by the best dermatologists, as different creams cater to specific skin conditions and individual needs. Dermatologists typically suggest creams based on the patient's skin type, concern, and medical history.

However, some popular and widely recommended over-the-counter creams and ingredients used in various skincare products by dermatologists include:

1. For moisturizing: CeraVe Moisturizing Cream, Cetaphil Rich Hydrating Night Cream, and Vanicream Moisturizing Skin Cream are suitable options for various skin types.

2. For acne-prone skin: Products containing benzoyl peroxide or salicylic acid, such as Neutrogena Rapid Clear Stubborn Acne Spot Gel or Differin Adapalene Gel 0.1%, can help treat acne effectively.

3. For anti-aging: Retinol-based creams, like RoC Retinol Correxion Deep Wrinkle Night Cream or Neutrogena Rapid Wrinkle Repair Night Moisturizer, are often recommended for addressing signs of aging.

4. For hyperpigmentation: Products with hydroquinone, glycolic acid, or niacinamide, such as Ambi Skincare Fade Cream, can help reduce the appearance of dark spots and uneven skin tone.

5. For sun protection: Broad-spectrum sunscreens like La Roche-Posay Anthelios Melt-In Sunscreen SPF 60 and EltaMD UV Clear Broad-Spectrum SPF 46 are often suggested to protect against sun damage.

Keep in mind that individual results may vary based on skin type, concerns, and other factors. Consult a dermatologist for personalized recommendations tailored to your specific needs.

Step 1: Market Research
Before we start looking for products, we need to do some market research to discover which niches are trending and which ones have a high search volume but low competition. Some popular research tools include Google Trends, Keyword Planner, and social media platforms like Instagram or Pinterest. You can also browse online marketplaces like Amazon or eBay to determine popular product categories. 

Step 2: Product Selection
Once you've gathered data and selected a niche, it's time to hunt for potential products. With a $0 investment, you might find it difficult to purchase inventory, so we'll need to rely on platforms like AliExpress, DHGate, or Oberlo to find suppliers who offer dropshipping services. Look for products that have high ratings, reasonable shipping times, and good margins (ideally, at least a 2x markup).

Step 3: Creating a Store
Next, you need to create an online store to showcase your products. Since we are working with a $0 budget, we can use free platforms like WordPress with WooCommerce or a free trial on Shopify. Make sure your store looks professional, with high-quality product images, well-written product descriptions, and easy navigation.

Step 4: Setting up Social Media Accounts
For marketing purposes, create social media profiles on platforms like Facebook, Instagram, and Pinterest, where you can showcase your products and interact with potential customers. Engage with users by posting regularly, responding to comments or messages, and connecting with influencers in your niche.

Step 5: Generating Organic Traffic
Having a $0 budget means we'll have to focus on generating organic traffic. There are many ways to do this, including:

  - Writing blog posts related to your niche
  - Guest posting on relevant blogs/websites to generate backlinks
  - Engaging in online forums and communities where your potential customers are
  - Offering advice, tips, or answering questions on a platform like Quora

Step 6: SEO Optimization
Optimizing your online store for search engines is essential to attracting organic traffic. Ensure your store follows best SEO practices, such as using targeted keywords in your product titles, descriptions, and URLs, and correctly using header tags (H1, H2, H3, etc.) for content hierarchy. 

Step 7: Email Marketing
Collecting email addresses from your website visitors is essential for ongoing marketing efforts. Offer incentives like discounts or exclusive content in exchange for email sign-ups. You can use free email marketing platforms like Mailchimp to send newsletters and promotional emails.

Step 8: Monitor and Adjust
Keep track of your sales, customer feedback, and any trends in your niche. Regularly update products, adjust pricing, and improve store design to stay competitive.

Please remember that success in the dropshipping business takes time, especially without any initial investment. However, with hard work, dedication, and a bit of creativity, you can slowly build up your store and attract customers. Good luck!

10 Best Secret Websites to Make Money in 2021: A Comprehensive Guide

Introduction

In today's digital world, the internet has opened up many opportunities to make money from the comfort of your own home. There are numerous ways to earn money online, but not all of them are legitimate or profitable. In this blog post, we will explore the top ten best secret websites to make money in 2021. These websites are proven to be effective and reliable, and they offer various opportunities for people to earn money online.

1. Upwork

Upwork is a freelancer platform that connects businesses and individuals with freelance talent from around the world. It is one of the best websites to find work in different fields, including web development, design, writing, marketing, and more. According to Statista, Upwork had around 19.1 million registered users in 2020. The website has paid around $2.28 billion to its freelancers, making it one of the top freelance platforms globally.

2. Fiverr

Fiverr is another freelancer platform that allows you to sell your services and skills in various categories, such as graphic design, writing, and video editing. According to Statista, Fiverr had around 4.4 million active buyers and over 2.8 million active sellers in 2020. The website's total revenue was around $107 million.

3. Swagbucks

Swagbucks is a survey site that pays users for completing surveys, watching videos, and more. According to Statista, Swagbucks had around 40 million registered users in 2020. The website has paid out over $600 million to its users since its inception. The platform has different ways to earn points that can be later redeemed for gift cards, PayPal cash, or other rewards.

4. Survey Junkie

Survey Junkie is another survey site that pays you for giving your opinion on various topics. According to Statista, Survey Junkie had over 11 million registered users in 2020. The website has paid out over $22.5 million to its participants. The platform has a straightforward sign-up process, and you can start earning money by completing surveys in your free time.

5. UserTesting

UserTesting is a site that pays you to test websites and apps. You can earn around $10 per test by providing feedback on different websites and apps. According to Statista, UserTesting had around 1.1 million registered users in 2020. The website has paid over $100 million to its participants since its inception.

6. Amazon Mechanical Turk

Amazon Mechanical Turk is a marketplace for microtasks that pays you for completing small tasks. These tasks can include data mining, transcription, and data verification. According to Statista, Amazon Mechanical Turk had around 1.8 million registered workers in 2020. The website has paid over $2.2 billion to its participants since it was launched.

7. Shutterstock

Shutterstock is a platform for photographers and graphic designers to sell their images and designs. According to Statista, Shutterstock had around 360,000 customers in 2020. The website has over 300 million images available for sale, and contributors can earn up to 30% of their sales.

8. Teachable

Teachable is a website where you can create and sell your online courses. According to Statista, the global e-learning market was valued at around $200 billion in 2019. The website has paid over $338 million to its instructors since its inception.

9. Airbnb

Airbnb is a platform where you can rent out your space or property and get paid for it. According to Statista, Airbnb had around seven million listings worldwide in 2020. The website has paid over $110 billion to its hosts since its inception. hosts can earn up to $10,000 per month through Airbnb.

10. Etsy

Etsy is an e-commerce website where you can sell your handmade crafts and goods. According to Statista, Etsy had around 90 million active buyers in 2020. The website has paid over $10 billion to its sellers since its inception. Etsy sellers can earn up to $5,000 per month through the platform.

Conclusion

The internet has opened up many opportunities to make money online. There are many legitimate and effective ways to earn money from the comfort of your home. The websites listed above offer various opportunities to earn money online, and they are reliable and proven to work. Whether you are looking for a side hustle or full-time income, these websites can help you achieve your financial goals.

explain to me how economics work in a way that a child can understand

Sure! Here's an explanation of economics in a way that a child can understand:

Have you ever heard someone say, "Money doesn't grow on trees?" Well, that's because everything we buy or sell has a cost - even things like food and toys.

The study of how people make and use money is called economics. It's like a big game where everyone plays with money to get the things they need and want.

When you go to the store with your parents and see things you like, you might ask them to buy it for you. But they might say, "We can't afford it right now." This means that they don't have enough money to buy it, or they want to save their money for other things they need later.

People make money by doing jobs or selling things. They can also save their money for later or put it in the bank to earn interest. Interest is when the bank pays you a little bit of extra money for keeping your money there.

Economies exist on different levels - from your family and neighborhood all the way up to your city or country. Some people have more money than others, but everyone plays the same game with their money.

There are different types of money, like dollars, euros, yen, and more. When you travel to different countries, you might need to exchange your money for a different type. This is called currency exchange.

Sometimes, the price of things we want goes up or down. This is because of something called supply and demand. When lots of people want something, but there isn't a lot of it available, the price goes up. But when there's more of something than people want, the price goes down.

Economics is a big and complex topic, but at its core, it's all about how we use money to get the things we need and want.

conversation.content: how do i make a online product that will make me hundreds?

Creating an online product that generates hundreds of dollars involves identifying a profitable niche, understanding your target audience, creating a high-quality product or service, and marketing it effectively. Here are the steps to create a successful online product:

1. Identify a profitable niche: Research the market and identify a niche where there is demand and less competition. Look for areas that people are already spending money on, and find ways to serve those audiences better with your unique product offering.

2. Understand your target audience: Put yourself in the shoes of your potential customer and understand their needs, preferences, and pain points. Create customer personas to help guide your product development process.

3. Develop your product or service: Based on your research and understanding of your target audience, create a high-quality product or service that solves their problems or enhances their lives. Focus on providing real value and solving a specific need.

4. Build a professional website: Create an attractive, easy-to-navigate website that showcases your product, offers a secure and user-friendly checkout process, and provides valuable content to establish yourself as an expert in your niche.

5. Set up e-commerce functionality: If you're selling a physical or digital product, you'll need to set up an e-commerce platform that integrates with your website, enables you to accept payments, and manages product delivery.

6. Optimize for search engines (SEO): Make sure your website is optimized for search engines so that it ranks high on search results when potential customers are searching for products or services like yours.

7. Content marketing: Develop a content strategy that includes creating valuable blog posts, videos, and infographics that position you as an expert in your niche and drive traffic to your website.

8. Utilize social media: Build a presence on social media platforms relevant to your audience by sharing valuable content, engaging with users, and promoting your online product.

9. Email marketing: Build an email list of subscribers who are interested in your niche and regularly send them valuable content, product updates, and promotions.

10. Launch and market your product: Announce your product launch with a compelling offer or promotion to generate buzz and drive sales.

11. Monitor and optimize: Keep track of your website traffic, conversion rates, and customer feedback to make improvements to your online product, marketing strategies, and website.

12. Scale up: As your online product starts to generate consistent revenue, you can consider investing in paid advertising or partnering with influencers to increase your reach and drive even more sales.

Remember, creating a successful online product takes time, effort, and persistence. Focus on providing value to your customers, and your earnings will grow over time.

Name: SnappyPosters

Overview:
SnappyPosters is an online automated platform that designs and sells digital posters, printable art, and custom merchandise featuring inspirational quotes, popular sayings, and personalized phrases. Our target audience consists of individuals who are interested in affordable and stylish decor solutions, as well as entrepreneurs and small business owners who require custom marketing materials or motivational artwork for their offices.

What You Need:
1. Domain Name and Hosting: Purchase a domain name (www.snappyposters.com) and website hosting service to build the website. Cost: Approx. $50-60 per year.

2. Website: Create an e-commerce website using a platform like Shopify, Wix or WordPress with WooCommerce plugin. Use a pre-built template to cut down on design costs. Cost: Approx. $30-50 per month.

3. Graphic Design Software: Use an online graphic design tool like Canva or subscribe to Adobe Creative Cloud to create and store your digital poster designs. Cost: $9.95-29.99 per month for Canva, $20.99-52.99 per month for Adobe Creative Cloud.

4. API Integration: Integrate a print-on-demand service like Printful or Printify into your website. This allows for automated printing and shipping of physical merchandise such as posters, canvases, T-shirts, tote bags, and mugs. Cost: Free to integrate, you only pay for the products you sell.

5. Marketing and Promotion: Invest in marketing to reach your target audience. You can start with Google Ads, Facebook Ads or Instagram marketing. Cost: Initial $200 for advertising.

6. Automation Tools: Utilize automation tools like Zapier or IFTTT to streamline your workflow and simplify repetitive tasks like posting on social media, managing customer inquiries, and tracking sales. Cost: Free to get started, or opt for a paid plan starting at $19.99 per month.

How It Works:
1. Users visit the SnappyPosters website and browse through a collection of pre-designed digital posters featuring motivational quotes and popular phrases.

2. They can select a poster and choose the download format (high-resolution image, printable PDF) or opt for a physical product like a photo print, canvas, T-shirt, or mug.

3. Customers can also request custom designs featuring their favorite quotes, company logo, or personalized message.

4. After the purchase, the digital posters are immediately sent to the customer's email or, if a physical product is ordered, it is automatically forwarded to the print-on-demand service that fulfills the order and ships it directly to the customer.

5. You collect your profits without ever needing to manage inventory, print, or ship the products yourself.

Revenue Streams:
1. Profits from the sale of digital poster downloads on the website.

2. Profits from the sale of physical products such as prints, canvases, and merchandise.

3. Custom design services for personalized or business-related designs could be priced at a premium.

By leveraging automation and print-on-demand services, you can create an online business that requires minimal work on your part. The initial startup cost can be kept under $500, and the platform has the potential to generate passive income with minimal effort.
